Joe Rosenthal's photograph of the flag-raising on Iwo Jima on Feb. 23, 1945 (Arts pages, May 17), speaks for itself. As I noted in The Saturday Evening Post 53 years ago, the first report of that event was also dramatic.

I was a member of the intelligence staff of the Third Marine Division, which was on shipboard still in reserve that day. My job was to keep current a situation map of the struggle ashore. Among the reports our radio intercepted were those from an observer in a light plane that constantly circled over the battlefield. He would report anything of significance, locating it on the map by target area. For example, a message would read, ''TA 182-L, two of our tanks firing into caves,'' or ''TA 183-H, six of our men crawling on a ridge.''

Around midmorning our radioman handed me a message that read ''TA 132-P,'' which I located on the map as the summit of Mount Suribachi. Turning back to finish the message, I read, ''One flag -- red, white and blue.''
